reviewText: Burt Reynolds always got along well with his stunt teams. Their fearless attitude and hard partying lifestyle (always after hours, NEVER during a shoot!) appealed to the inner nature of a box office superstar who found himself so trapped by his own fame that he couldn't enjoy the fruits of his success in the way he wanted to. He gave stunt buddy Hal Needham a directing stint for the first Bandit film and even made Hooper as an homage to a lifestyle Reynolds' celebrity status kept just out of reach.We all know the story. Lightning struck and S&TB; became an unexpected runaway smash. A sequel was inevitable. So what what wrong and what went right? Part of the problem was Reynolds' own ego. A funny thing happens to some people when they achieve massive success. They begin to believe their own press releases and think that people love THEM and not the things they've produced. It also happened to Stephen King who spent years writing terrible books. He came to believe that his name on the cover would be enough to move copies and he needn't worry about the quality on the pages inside. As his sales began to slide he created an alter ego (Richard Bachman) and re-taught himself the craft that got him stardom in the first place. The best example of this in Burt Reynolds' career comes in the middle of S&TBII; when his character meets a man that doesn't buy into the whole "Bandit myth." Grabbing the man by the scruff of his shirt, Reynolds turns to Sally Field and says, "Who the heck does he think he IS?" Her reply, "I think you need to ask yourself that," sums up the entire problem with the film.In the first Bandit movie, Needham quickly gave up on getting the beloved Jackie Gleason to stick to scripted dialogue. Given the chance to perform "blue" adult humor after years of being trapped by the constraints of televisions censorship limitations, Gleason went wild. He chewed the scenery, made up his own lines, and basically carried the humor of the entire film on his back. The crowds came for the hot car chases but they came back for repeated viewings to enjoy a comic master at the very top of his game. Needham wisely sets Gleason free in the second film and once again Gleason displays the reason why his career spanned so many decades. He is, was, and always shall be, one of the absolute masters at his craft.Unfortunately, Reynolds, Reed, and Deluise spend a lot of time ad-libbing themselves and only Dom Deluise really has the comic chops to make it work. Reynolds shows no nuance whatsoever comedically and spends the bulk of the film mugging it up in the mistaken belief that his looks and the popularity of the character he is playing will automatically make him charming and funny. No such luck.I caught Jerry Reed live some years back. He was reduced to playing at a high school gymnasium in a rural North Carolina town. He spent more time name-dropping and talking about his "star status" than singing and by the midpoint of the show, half of the crowd had already headed for the exits. Unlike Mr. King, Jerry never learned his lesson.The end result is a movie that has twice the mugging and ham acting as the first with roughly half of the car chases and very little of the charm. At a time when people had come to realize that alcoholism destroys the lives of entire families, Reynolds portrays it as a good-natured and funny thing that can be cured with some situps and a few days on the wagon. Simply put, Reynolds had lost touch with the things that made him a star in the first place and the result was a film that might have worked ten years earlier, but was sadly out of place in 1980.The film is still worth the ride for several reasons, not the least of which is the chance to watch Jackie Gleason unchained and running wild for the pure joy of it. Also, the crew discovered an abandoned roller coaster that was slated for demolition and Needham and Reynolds were able to convince the owner to allow them to destroy the ancient ride on camera. It makes for one of the most amusing and memorable moments of the film trilogy. Dom Deluise, given little to work with but a massive living and breathing prop, has some moments of true brilliance, not the least of which is his lament that he can't properly examine the elephant in the film without a set of OB-GYN stirrups.S&TBII; almost works despite the mailed-in performances of Reynolds and Reed. Although it really isn't up to the energy of the original on any levels, it was still fun to revisit the characters and there are worse ways to kill an evening than popping the movie into the DVD player and kicking back for a laugh or two. It's worth a rental and even worth purchasing if you can find it in the bargain bin for five bucks or so as I did. My wife and I bought it with the idea of having friends over for a "Bandit Double Feature" and the laughs and nostalgia the two films provided reminded us that movies don't have to be pretentious and full of social messages. Sometimes they're just made for the fun of it and are there just to be enjoyed.I won't even comment on the third film. I paid for a ticket to see it in theaters when it was released so the studio has already gotten more money out of me than that film ever deserved. But the second film of the series still has enough juice (barely) to be worth viewing - especially as a companion piece to the original.

reviewText: "Smokey and the Bandit II" finds Burt Reynolds, Jerry Reed & Sally Field returning in their roles as The Bandit, Cledus & Carrie. The Enis Brothers (Paul Williams & Pat McCormick) once again goad our hero into accepting a bet that The Bandit cannot deliver a pregnant elephant from Miami to Dallas in a prescribed amount of time. Unlike the first original film, this sequel has a lot going against it: a silly storyline, an out of place Burt Reynolds & Jerry Reed - both of whom look uncomfortable in their respective roles & a myriad of guest stars. Guest stars??? The only thing this sequel has going for it, is the timely comedic portrayal of Jackie Gleason as Sheriff Buford T. Justice. Make that two things: Dom DeLuise as a doctor is "SATB II's" other saving grace. Both Gleason & DeLuise are masters of comedy & comedic timing. If it weren't for their contributions, this film would garner one star for it's silly plot alone. Another thing "SATB II" has going against it, is the writers' sense of geography. The desert's in western Texas, not on the border with Louisiana (an allusion to the trucker-law enforcement vehicular smash derby three-quarters through the movie)! Word of the wise is, only purchase this title if you're a die-hard "SATB" fanatic - in which case you should purchase the Pursuit Pack featuring all three movies on one single disc instead, which is a much better bargain. Otherwise, avoid "SATB II" at all costs & skip to "SATB, Part 3" instead.R.I.P., Jackie Gleason, Jerry Reed & Dom DeLuise.

reviewText: I wanted to like this film.I saw the first classic movie when it was new back when I was only 7 years old at the movies in 1977 but I hadn't seen it since the early 80s.So recently I was at a yardsale and they had on VHS Smokey I and II.I had never seen part 2 but I figured I would watch them in order.So I put in part I and by the time it was over I figured I would order it on DVD soon.However, part 2 came across as such a corny "Jump the shark" rehash of the first one that I considered turning it off half way through.Sally Fields looked great and Jerry Reed still had his natural good ol boy charm.That being said, the characters of Bandit and Smokey were really forced and came off as weak and clearly trying too hard to recapture their original humor.As a Steelers fan, seeing Bradshaw and Joe Greene was the highlight.

reviewText: "Daddy, look at that big ugly alligator.", "That reminds me, I gotta call your moma tonight." THIS MOVIE IS FUNNY!!!The first thing I noticed about SMOKEY and the BANDIT 2 was the quality of the digital transfer to DVD. It is done so well, I felt like I was watching a movie made a year ago(aside the old cars and clothes).I'm 36 and this movie brought back tons of memories.  "Son, why isn't your gun loaded?", "It's too heavy when I put bullets in it, Daddy." This movie is full of hilarious one liners. I found myself to be in a great mood after watching this movie. There's a semi-sentimental tone that is, at times alittle cheesy but still, touching and not too overboard.Everyone is fantastic in this movie. Even the gas station attendant is brilliantly funny. I really can't think of one negative thing to say about SB2.It's as good, if not better than, the first BANDIT. I give it 2 thumbs up and a MUST SEE for anyone who loves to laugh.
summary: I LOVE THIS MOVIE! Daddy, look at that big ugly alligator...

reviewText: The first movie is great and the second movie is still really good .Jump in and buckle up for a wild ride in the fast lane of laughter as Burt Reynolds (1936 - ) and Sally Field (1946 - ) team up again to take on Jackie Gleason (1916-1987) in this sequel to one top action-adventure comedies ever ! This time , the notorious Bandit (Reynolds) and his beautiful companion Carrie (Field) find themself involved in a mission of epic proportions: Transporting a pregnant elephant cross-country in 24 hours or less ! Hot on their heels is archenemy Sheriff Buford T. Justice (Gleason) who wows to finaly put the Bandit hehind bars . The duo find themself in a race against time , a battle of wits and test of skills in this non-stop , high-octane comedy hit . High Quality Transfer .

reviewText: This review will go as a tribute to the great Hal Needam who directed the "Smokey" movies as well as other memorable stunt-related films. He passed away recently with Hollywood barely taking any notice ( Shame on you 'industry' people). This sequel to "Smokey and the Bandit" was even better than the original.  Over the top stunts, crazy characters, and all sorts of 'non-actors' aka fans and real people used as extras just like in the first film. Burt and Sally returning as well as the legendary Jackie Gleason as Sheriff Beuford T. Justice, Esq. Halarious pranks, high jinx and the funny Bassett Hound riding shotgun with Jerry is so much fun you have to watch it again. Full-throttle and crossing into more states than you can shake a stick at, The Bandit rules and gets himself into so much trouble, he almost didn't return for Part 3!( Actually, Burt Reynolds didn't want to do a third movie, feeling that it was time to direct his own action films, "Sharkey's Machine" being his best) The producers talked him into a tiny "smile and wave" at the very end of part 3-ripping off the fans-oh well) .
Title: N/A

reviewText: I think it's because I grew up having both Smokey 1 and 2 on an old beta tape that I was exposed at a young age to not notice the flaws of this film, and just enjoyed the reunion of some good ole' boys heading to Miami to pick up an elephant and have a hell of a demolition derby in the end. But seeing the film now, I can see why so many people say they do not like this sequel. However, to say this is one of the worst films of all time is going too far. Sure you could point out the flaws...Q: what the heck is that red stuff the Burdettes use to get revenge on the other guy running for Governor? Is it paint or something?Q: The Burdettes overhear the Governors conversation of wanting a package from Miami delivered in 9 days, so they call upon Bandit and Snowman to get it for them expecting that the delivery of the crate will get them elected Governor? HOW? If things did go to plan and a crate, in this case, an elephant, was to be delivered on time, how the heck would that get the Burdettes feet in the door?Q: How come no one knows Snowman was involved in the bootlegging of the 1sy movies plot? Yet here he is introduced winning a truck rodeo race, and not a wanted fugitive? And is Bandit still wanted? Is he hiding out? Is that why know one knows where to find him but Snowman? But more importantly, why did Buford stop chasing him?Q: Carrie/"Frog" is called back because Bandit is a drunken has been since she left, so she helps to get Bandit back into shape before the haul to Miami. Damn Snowman and Frog know a hell of a fitness training tactic to get a man back into shape in 4 days!!! Imagine the money they could have made just selling their program alone, how much would you be willing to pay for an exorcise program that gets you so fit in 4 days, you can out-run race horses???? More then $400,000 i'm sure!Q: Why does Carrie even need to go on the trip to Miami and back? She got him in shape, why stick around? And why even ride with Bandit?A: Because movies need a sexy lead female role to keep viewer interest.Q: Why is Bandit even playing "blocker" again to a trip that is supposed to be "strictly legit"A: Because it took so damn long to get Bandit back into shape that he brought the need of playing blocker on himself... blah blah blah...Q: What kind of Animal Cruelty laws where NOT in place in the early 1980's that allowed Elephants to be kept in crates in warehouses for 3 weeks quarantine? Let alone the fact of since when do Elephants get shipped as cargo in crates to begin with?Q: How did beautiful Buford know Bandit, Snowman and Frog where at the docks in Miami? Who told him they where even going there, let alone they would be there at that exact time of day he blocked their exit off?Q: If a doctor says an elephant can't be moved for 24 hours, then you see the elephant cry and we have a little jealous elephant of the night scene... why is the elephant back in the truck the very next day?Q: Since when do bridge controllers allow a car, especially a cop car, to be purposely allowed to fall into the water when it's hanging by a thread on an opened bridge?A: They where Bandits friends and where prepared to be trialed on attempted murder for him, because he's that damn lovable.Q: Bandit wants to do the run to be a legend again. How is delivering a package going to do this? Bootlegging beer is one thing, but if you opened the paper tomorrow and headline read, "Two guys delivered a package from Miami to Texas within 9 days!!!" could you really care less and think of these guys as legendary?Q: How did Bufford call for reinforcements from Canada and have 20 or so county mounties arrive in Texas within a 12 hour time period... give or take a few hours.Q: What was the point of Jackie Gleason's alternate characters of brother Gaylord and whats-his-name being in this movie at all?A: Jackie wanted to play some other characters for his own personal amusement... Q: Did they contribute to the movie? A: No.Q: How did Snowman unpack the elephant and doc at the side of the desert so quickly, all while calling in reinforcements and appearing miles away on the other side of the desert in such a short period of time?A: He has a really fast truck!Q: How did Bandit know where Carrie was sitting at the end? Was there only ONE bus stop in the whole of Louisiana or Texas or wherever she is at that time?A: Don't say "other truckers spotted her and CB'd her location in", it's like looking for a needle in a haystack.Q: Bandit tows the Elephant and her new born Dumbo behind the trans-am, in trailers with not gates at the rear to prevent the elephants from falling off if the car was to speed up too fast; therefor, the last scene is of Bufford in a bus right behind them in "hot pursuit"... so how did Bandit escape that one? He couldn't speed off without killing the elephant, and I know Snowmans already done a magical fast unloading of the elephant in the previous scenes, but how could he ever be THAT fast to stop a bus coming up fast from behind?A: Bandit sped off, killing the elephants in the progress, hence solving his problem on feeding the things, which no one is seen doing in the movie at all, and then speeding off away from Bufford T Justice... keeping himself out of jail, but at the same time losing Frog who cannot believe he would allow the elephant and it's baby to be killed, and Bandit's reputation is completely destroyed for all time. And we know he did escape, because the whole plot of Smokey 3 is Buford coming out of retirement to chase the Bandit, because he never caught him.- Another possibility is Snowman intercepted the Bus in his truck, in which Bufford would not have been dumb enough to not have called in for backup, which would result in a 100 Texas county mounties looking for one 1980 Pontiac trans-am doing 5 miles an hour with two elephants behind it. Which is a sure capture of the Bandit, unless they made a run for it, dumping the elephants behind... which his ego wouldn't allow, as Frog would not like it, and it would damage his reputation of being a chicken... oh wait, he's know for running from the law... hmmmmSo I guess that there is a lot of reasons why people might find this movie to be no justice to the original, seeing a drunken has-been Bandit and not liking the on-screen arguing of a couple of stars who really where going through a divorce or separation in the real world at the time. But I kind of liked the way Carrie busted Beaus ego a few times, and showed him that you can be as cocky as you like, it's not going to make you happy in the long run.The other thing I love in this movie is the worlds biggest game of chicken and the demolition derby scene. Many say it's not so great, probably due to car wreck scenes in classic movies where of rare and special cars that made a car lover cry seeing one go over a cliff or be destroyed, but to me, seeing a bunch of run down old wrecks being demolished was fun, it was a bit of a cartoon-like scene in parts, but overall, it was entertaining. And for those who say that scene is one of the worst on film ever, then try denying it's the guiness world record holder of most car wrecks in a movie? It did amount to something after all.Some have said Jackie Gleason did not contribute much to this film, or they feel he should have had a better role... I think he did a great job of reprising Bufford. He was a little whackier this time around, but he was still the same character. Sure, the alternate characters and the "heemo gage?" scenes where not that funny, and didn't make much sense, but that was probably something Jackie improved and wanted to do, so at least he was having fun doing the film, and he mustve enjoyed it enough if he agreed to sign on for the 3rd sequel.And another factor I haven't mentioned yet... Dom Deluise, what a classic! His portrayal of a bad speaking Italian gynecologist was priceless. It was a great character for him, and after the Cannonball Run movies, it was awesome to see Burt and Dom doing another film together. Dom was hilarious as this character, and he saved most of the middle of this movie by himself. If Dom had not have been brought in, the film probably would have been a real dud.I know my pros are not out-weighing the cons, and a lot of unanswered questions are the result of seeing this movie, and yes, I do strongly agree, its not where near as good as the first movie, but it's not all that bad as people are saying it is. And neither is Cannonball Run II. I just don't get why people slam these films so much and say they should never have been done, the fact is, they are done, and are not going anywhere, no matter what you say, and if you would just sit back and try to enjoy the films, you might get something out of it, sure it wont be what the originals did, but seriously, they are not that bad. And it's easy to say Smokey and The Bandit 3 had a reasonable plot, but even so, it's NOT as good as this one, and part 2 is NOT the worst of the 3 movies. (or 7 if you consider those other things to be part of this)Seriously, if you wanna see bad movies, go find "The Slaughterhouse Massacre", "Mr. Accident", "Home Alone 4" or any episodes of "The Hills" and then watch this movie after it, and then tell me which ones rank as the worst movies of all time, and which ones that aren't so bad, you just expected more from it compared to the original?

reviewText: Burt Reynolds and director Hal Needham should have ended their stunt-filled collaboration after "Hooper." Instead, they churned out "Smokey and the Bandit II" (1980) - a mostly joyless sequel to the high-spirited original. The welcome return of Jackie Gleason, Sally Field and Jerry Reed is negated by Burt's sour attitude toward the whole enterprise. Needham stages a lavish demolition-derby climax, but only Gleason appears to be having fun.

reviewText: In this comedy sequel, It's been a few years since Cletus Snow(Jerry Reed)and Bo Darville aka the Bandit(Burt Reynolds) made their famous 28-hour run to Texas for a few cases of Coors. Bandit is now a washed-up has-been living in the past, until Big Enos and Little Enos make him another offer: Transport a live Elephant across country in 3 days or less as the Bandit & Cledus along with Carrie(Sally Field)return for more wild car chases, hilarity and near-misses with the law fill as the disgruntled Sheriff Justice(Jackie Gleason) is hot on the trail of his old archenemy, who is attempting to complete his newest gig-driving a pregnant elephant across state lines.SMOKEY & THE BANDIT-PART 2 takes me back to memory lane to when I was 7 going on 8 years old during its theatrical release in the Summer of 1980 and when I saw it on HBO for the very first time in the Summer of 1981.
